text: We asked whether dexamethasone ( Dex ) and cyclosporin A ( CsA ) inhibit <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene transcription by interfering with the activity of nuclear proteins that bind to the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

text: Nuclear extracts from primary human T lymphocytes were analyzed by electrophoretic DNA mobility shift assays .

Both Dex and CsA inhibited the binding of transcription factors AP-1 and NF-AT , but not of NF-kB and OCT-1 / OAF , to their corresponding sites on the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter .

text: To correlate changes in nuclear factor binding in vitro with transcriptional activity in vivo and define the structural requirements for <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter repression , we used transient DNA transfections .

text: Jurkat cells were transfected with plasmids containing either the intact <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter or its AP-1 , NF-AT , and NF-kB motifs .
Dex inhibited the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter and the AP-1 , but not the NF-AT and NF-kB plasmids .
In contrast , CsA inhibited the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter and the NF-AT , but not the AP-1 and NF-kB plasmids .

These results suggest that in human T lymphocytes both Dex and CsA inhibited <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene transcription through interference with transcription factors AP-1 and NF-AT .

text: We propose that , while maximum inhibition may involve interaction with both transcription factors , AP-1 is the primary target of Dex .
